item.title: Nintendo Switch 2 sales may be lagging a bit in the West, but its impact on Japan's console market is undeniable
item.content:encoded:
With the menace of price hikes looming over every piece of gaming hardware and early 2026 reports that Nintendo Switch 2 was below Switch 1's sales curve over its first December period in the US and Europe, many have started to wonder if we were looking at a strong start with bad legs for the newest hybrid console. But, in Japan at least, that doesn't seem to be the case.

Via Automaton West (from original reports by Kadokawa Game Linkage and Famitsu), we have learned Japan's console game market saw a big boost year-on-year in 2025, with a 138.8 percent growth across the board. It reached 418.13 billion yen, which amounts to around $2.64 billion. These figures are based on physical software and hardware sales as reported through the end of 2025, so they include the bulk of the Christmas shopping we typically see every December.

Mind you, we haven't seen the more specific data for the Christmas period, but overall, Japan's console game market is looking remarkably strong, with the Switch 2 outpacing Switch 1's first year (and every other console's, it seems) in Nintendo's home turf. Things look even better when we take into account that digital sales, DLC, and in-game purchases are not accounted for in the aforementioned reports.

Moreover, the original Switch continued to perform well given its age and the presence of Nintendo's second hybrid console, with 1.52 million units reportedly sold in 2025, putting it above PS5's sales in Japan last year. It must be noted other charts aren't as optimistic, but the information shared shows the Japanese market favours Nintendo's hardware.

When it comes to best-selling physical games in Japan, Mario Kart World (2.668 million units) and Pokémon Legends: Z-A (2.534 million units) conquered the top spots with the Switch 1 & 2 releases combined.

Looking at what early 2026 has in store for us and the strong focus on iconic JRPG series like Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest making the jump to Switch 2 before first-party heavy hitters start to arrive, we're not expecting a slowdown of that market's growth.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/nintendo-switch-2-boosted-japan-console-market-in-2025

item.title: Marathon soars to Steam's Top Sellers after release date reveal
item.content:encoded:
Marathon has swiftly climbed Steam's Top Sellers list following the reveal of its 5th March release date.

Bungie's extraction shooter, which has up until now lived in the realm of closed betas and behind-closed-doors tests, was made available for pre-order overnight. In those midnight hours many wallets were opened by keen members of the public, landing on the number seven spot.

It lies currently behind Arc Raiders, at third. There's also EA Sports FC, Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora, and Kingdom Come Deliverance 2. Those three currently ranking well due to substantial discounts on the PC marketplace. Marathon is currently retailing for £34.99 / $39.99.

It's a great first showing for the extraction shooter, which has until now had to power through a turbulent development process at Bungie. Only last month its art lead left the company, and prior to that the game underwent drastic design changes to the game following a mixed reception to initial public betas.

It follows on the heels of Arc Raiders, another extraction shooter which took the world by storm last year, growing in popularity through the winter holidays. Whether that game has set the stage for wider extraction shooter popularity, allowing Marathon to launch to a comparable level of success, will be made clear as early as March.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/marathon-soars-to-steams-top-sellers-after-release-date-reveal

item.title: Cyberpunk 2077 VR mod removed by CD Projekt after its creator wouldn't release it for free
item.content:encoded:
"They give absolutely zero f***s."

A mod for Cyberpunk 2077 which enabled the game to be playable in VR has been removed following a legal takedown notice by CD Projekt.

Earlier this week, prolific VR modder Luke Ross said the Cyberpunk 2077 and Witcher 3 studio had issued a DMCA notice against him, requesting the removal of his Cyberpunk 2077 VR mod.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

However, it wasn't actually the mod itself that the team took issue with. Rather, CD Projekt requested the removal after Ross put his mod behind a Patreon paywall, effectively selling its content. This is at odds with the Cyberpunk 2077 studio's official 'Fan Guidelines' document, which states any content created with its games can not be used for commercial purposes.

"We're happy for you to accept reasonable donations in connection with your fan content, but you're not allowed to make people pay for it or have it behind any sort of paywall (e.g. don't make content only available to paid subscribers)," this document reads.

Despite this, Ross has admitted he feels "bitter" about being forced to remove his Cyberpunk 2077 VR mod. "In the end it amounted to the same iron-clad corpo logic: every little action that a company takes is in the name of money, but everything that modders do must be absolutely for free," Ross wrote in a very to the point Patreon post (thanks, roadtovr).

"As usual they stretch the concept of 'derivative work' until it's paper-thin, as though a system that allows visualising 40+ games in fully immersive 3D VR was somehow built making use of their intellectual property," Ross continued.

"And as usual they give absolutely zero f***s about how playing their game in VR made people happy." According to @SynthPotato, Ross generates $20k monthly from paid mods.

Back in 2022, our Ian took Ross' Cyberpunk 2077 mod out for a spin. You can check out his adventures in the video below.

Despite the legal issues between Ross and CD Projekt, he is not giving up his VR modding endeavours. In his same post, he announced the release of a new VR mode for Larian's acclaimed Baldur's Gate 3.

Elsewhere in CDPR-related news, earlier this month Cyberpunk 2 creative director Igor Sarzynski revealed why male V disappeared from the game's marketing after Cyberpunk 2077 launched its 2.0 update.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/cyberpunk-2077-vr-mod-removed-by-cd-projekt-after-its-creator-wouldnt-release-it-for-free
